now we're going to discuss this a little

and that happened right before

student loan debt very high savings rate

bursting that right now record numbers
of Americans are rolling in government

plans known as income driven repayment
are on track to send the US student loan
program into negative territory now this
is coming from the Department of
Education inspector general and the
plans known as income driven repayment
these are set monthly payments as a
percentage of borrower's earnings and
typically forgive balances after 10 to
25 years depending on the borrower's
career field and debt amounts and all
that overall borrowers in income driven
repayment will repay less than what they
originally borrowed now think about this
for a second they needed to modify the
student loans
for the students coming out of college
because they could not find a

to make it easier for them to repay but
they're gonna pay back a lot less than
they borrowed because the system is not
working the way it's supposed to be
working it's breaking down and what I
mean by this even though the

one percent it makes no difference
because the jobs the quality of jobs
it's absolutely terrible and those
individuals coming out of college
they're having a very difficult time

we're seeing this now what we're seeing
right now is nearly 40% of student loans

according to the report by Brookings

according to the IG report the income
driven repayment program alone will cost

it can't now think about this for a
